stem: A 45-year-old client is 24 hours post-craniotomy for a tumor resection. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: SITUATION: The patient is a 45-year-old female, 24 hours post-craniotomy for right frontal lobe tumor resection. The subgaleal drain is in place. BACKGROUND: Surgical intervention to remove a brain tumor. Baseline neurological status was intact prior to surgery. ASSESSMENT: At 10:00, the client reports a persistent 'drip' sensation at the back of her throat and an escalating headache, rated 7/10. Upon inspection, the dressing is moist. Pharyngeal exam reveals clear fluid. A bedside halo test was performed. RECOMMENDATION: The nurse recommends immediate evaluation for possible cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak, neurological assessment, and potential adjustment of the subgaleal drain. Consider pain management strategies for headache.

tabs.content:

actionOptions.text: Keep the head of the bed (HOB) elevated to 30 degrees
Notify the neurosurgeon immediately of the drainage findings
Instruct the client to blow their nose periodically to clear the drainage
Place a tight pressure dressing over the nose and throat

parameterOptions.text: Neurological status and presence of nuchal rigidity

rationale.correct: This client has a Post-Operative CSF Leak (c2), as evidenced by the 'Halo' sign on the dressing, clear 'salty' drainage in the throat, and positive glucose testing (since mucus usually doesn't contain glucose). A CSF leak is a major risk factor for meningitis. Priority actions are to promote drainage while maintaining low ICP (HOB 30 degrees) (a1) and notifying the surgeon for potential repair (a2). Key parameters: Neuro/Meningitis assessment (p1) and monitoring the drainage itself (p2).
clinicalPearls: The Halo Test: A drop of drainage on gauze; if blood stays in the center and a clear ring forms around it, it's CSF.
Never suction the nose or allow the patient to blow their nose if a CSF leak is suspected; it can increase pressure or introduce bacteria into the brain.
Clear drainage from the nose (Rhinorrhea) or ear (Otorrhea) after head trauma or brain surgery is CSF until proven otherwise.

questionTrap.trap: Instructing the patient to blow their nose to get a better sample.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Contraindicated! Do NOT shove anything into the nose or use pressure to clear it; this can cause air to enter the brain (Pneumocephalus).

mnemonic.title: CSF Check
mnemonic.expansion: C-Clear fluid. S-Salty taste. F-Font (Halo) ring.
